desc: The Assiniboia IRS opened. Members of the Oblate Order had been residing in the building since June 1958, though students did not arrive at the IRS until September. The classroom block at the I RS consisted of four classrooms for Grades 8 to 10.
Five classrooms were in operation at the IRS for Grades 8 to 11.
Grade 12 was added to the IRS.
The federal government and the Oblate Indian Eskimo Commission (INDIANESCOM) signed an agreement for the operation of the Assiniboia IRS.
Grade 8 was discontinued at the IRS by the beginning of the fall term. Five classrooms continued to operate for Grades 9 to 12.
Six classrooms were in operation at the IRS.

In September 1965, Grade 9 was no longer taught at the IRS. Grades 10 to 12 continued to be taught in five classrooms for the 1965/66 school year. During the 1966/67 school year, four classrooms operated at the IRS for Grades 10 to 12.
Assiniboia IRS became a hostel only, and all residents were sent to local high schools in Winnipeg for classroom instruction. The gymnasium and library were still used for sports and study.
The management of Assiniboia IRS was transferred to the Government of Canada.

The Bosco Centre of the Roman Catholic Church agreed to provide chaplaincy services to the IRS from September 1969 to August 1970, from September 1971 to August 1972, and from September 1972 to IRS closure in June 1973.

During the 1972/73 school year, the federal government Winnipeg Guidance Office moved into the chapel of the IRS, and the classroom block, except for part of the basement, was rented to the Children's Home of Winnipeg as a day centre. Documents at the time indicate that the classroom block had been 'unused for several years'.

additionalInformation.notes: A complaint was made that a boys' supervisor allegedly referred to IRS pupils using derogatory names.

In November 1967, complaints alleged that a Supervisor / Guidance Counsellor made disparaging remarks about some of the IRS pupils. In March 1968, the IRS Principal admitted that the staff member was not counselling the students properly; she was informed of her errors and told that more drastic action would be taken if the inappropriate behaviour continued.
In October 1968, a student struck a member of the domestic staff.
A report indicated that there had been a recent outbreak of infectious hepatitis at the IRS.
An inspection report of food services noted that students at the IRS ranged in age from 15 to 20 years old..
Due to overcrowded conditions at the IRS, a number of students were transferred to St. Benedict's Academy and St. Charles Academy.
